From Wreford Homemakers
Mrs. Eva Jamieson, Sec.
May 1948

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Mrs. Mrs. Mrs. Mrs.

Address Address Address

Birthplace Birthplace Birthplace

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? 16-23-29
Where had you been living before that? Humboldt, Nebraska
For how many people did you prepare meals? Four
How far was it to your nearest store? 8 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? 2 or 3 times a year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Oatmeal - sugar - salt - crackers -
Flour - syrup - tea - rice - prunes

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Five Roses
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.80
How much did you use graham flour? 20 lb. per year
Whole wheat flour? No
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? _______ What year? _______
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 95¢
What other grain products did you use? Wheat, Oats, and Cooking Bran
Cornmeal? 10¢ lb. flour? _______ Whole wheat? _______ Farina? _______
Other? _______
Did you grind your own wheat for porridges? No
How did you grind it? _______

   - How many times did you use insecticide in the last 3 weeks? ______
   - How much did you use? ______

   - What brand of flour did you use in the last month? ______
   - In what quantities did you buy it? ______

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ... 2 or 4 lbs. ... 20¢ lb., about.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? Can't remember - 5¢ lb.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ... Edwardsburg.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ... 1 lb.

At what price? ... $5.9 for 10 lb. pail.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ... For a year had no butter or milk. Then had own cows.

Butter? ... Had 2 doz here.

What was the price of butter? ... 18¢ to 25¢.

Did you pack eggs for winter? ... 3 doz.

Did you make butter? ... No.

Did you make cheese? ... No.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... Bought 50 lbs beef butchered a small pig.

How did you get fresh meat? ... Bought some from the Grand Trunk R.R. when it was being built.

How often did you get fresh meat? ... Once in 2 or 3 weeks.

How did you preserve meat? ... Brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ... No.

If so what year was it organized? ... Not organized until 1913-14.

Did you use game? ... Yes.

What kinds? ... Wild ducks, a few antelope.

For how long? ...

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... Lots of fish in the spring, in the Saline and Wolverine creeks.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Fresh.

Kinds? ... Suckers - pickerel and pike.
3. SUGAR AND STARCH

In what quantity did you buy flour last month? 25 lbs. 10 lbs. 20 lbs.

What was the price for a ton of sugar? 54¢ 60¢ 70¢

What was the price for a barrel of flour? 8¢ 9¢ 10¢

What was the price of the 10 lb. bag of flour? 10¢ 12¢ 14¢

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get milk in the early days? For a dollar.

Had no butter or milk. I am not sure.

That was the price of butter? 10¢ 25¢ 50¢

Did you make butter? Yes No

Did you make cheese? Yes No

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, and mutton.

How did you get fresh meat? Bought at market, killed by family.

How often did you get fresh meat? Twice a week, once a week.

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "store" kept in your neighborhood? Yes No

If so, what was it called? 7th Regiment, with 1913-14

Did you use ham? Yes No

For how long? A few months

Did you use fish? Yes No

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh

Kind(s)? Smoked, salted, and pickled.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose. At what price? 3 lbs. for $2.00.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? $18.75. That other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store? Raised them.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1926. Cabbage 1926. Carrots 1926. Onions 1926.

Turnips 1926. Beets 1926.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 3 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box.

What weight? 10 lb. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes.

That was the price of prunes? $4.

That other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

All dried fruits were bought at Eaton's. Country stores did not handle them.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? About 1914.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1935—1920.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? Not much.

Did you make your own vinegar? Vinegar was very hard to buy in pioneer days. Sent for vinegar seeds once. Made a little was not very satisfactory.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well. We had very good water.**

How far was this water from your home? **In the yard.**

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **Pail.**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

As we lived in Pokomis since 1940, the water is carried into the house by the water man. And is good water. Some have their own water systems.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you not savor for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, album, dugout)

Well: We had very good water.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) Pails.

Here was an airline water supply, rationing any chances which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

As we lived in Montana since 1940, the water is carried into the house by the water main.

And is good water, some have their own water systems.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Did both.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes. Good ashes? No.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Laundry Soap.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the cliffs.

Some time had to go many miles.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

After new towns sprang up on the C.P.R. and C.N.R. were able to get coal. How many are using fuel oil in both heaters and furnaces.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Enterprise. Don't know.

That year was it purchased? 1896. Price? $30.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Mostly tin and granite ware.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Mostly granite ware, some earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1913.

Aluminum? 1913.

16. **Packaging and Containers**

   Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

   From 1906 to about 1916, most food was sold by the pound & sold in paper bags. Afterwards was packaged in cardboard or cloth bags.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   Oatmeal for breakfast always. Although there was no milk for a year. Always had good bread and syrup. Hardly any vegetables then but generally meat of some kind, and plenty of dried fruits. Potatoes and baked beans regular. Fish all summer, occasionally a duck. 2 children 6 and 7 yrs. My husband - my self.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? .......1926....... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   Nothing different from other days except a fruit cake made with dried apples. The family only were present.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   No -
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family or names.

Oatmeal for breakfast always. Also, there was no milk for a year. Always had good bread and syrup. Usually had vegetables, but generally meat of some kind, and plenty of dried fruits. Potatoes and baked beans regularly. Fish all summer, occasionally a duck.

2 children, 6 and 7 yrs., my husband—myself.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and five chair approvers at any one time.

Nothing different from other days except a fruit-cake made with dried apples.

The family only were present.

19. Local food produced foods? Give example.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Diet more restricted and monotonous. Too much fried foods and few green vegetables or fresh fruit except citrus which we grew in quantities and some wild fruit as Saskatoon and choke cherries.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Always grew own vegetables, had eggs, milk, butter, fowl and meat. Never have relied entirely on prepared foods—meals home prepared as far as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

The pioneer merchants prior to the coming of the railway in 1908 teamed supplies from Regina to Lumsden Beach, from whence they were taken by boat up Long Lake to Watertown or Kelly's Landing (near Imperial). On the east side of Long Lake supplies were teamed from Craven.
Diet more restricted and spontaneous. Too much fried foods and few green vegetables or half fruit except citrus which are grown in Greenhouses and come wild fruit as blackberries and choke cherries.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods? (Give an early date and adduce reasons if possible).

Always grew own vegetables, had eggs, milk, butter - food and meat never have relied entirely on prepared foods - meals home prepared as far as possible.
